Award.AwardTitle: Track 2 CS10K: Expanding Computer Science Curriculum, Diversity, and Teacher Preparedness in Montana High Schools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Montana in Missoula, in partnership with Montana State University in Bozeman, Montana Tech (MTech) in Butte, and the Salish Kootenai Tribal College (SKC), will undertake a planning effort for a larger statewide initiative to introduce CS high school courses that engage and retain a diverse population of students, promote and advocate for these courses, and prepare high school teachers to offer and sustain them. The expanded curriculum will include material from the Joy and Beauty of Computing course recently created and piloted by one of the collaborating institutions of this proposal (MSU), and the new AP principles course currently being developed by NSF and the College Board. Dual credit opportunities will be available for students. In addition, the curriculum will be supported with activities proven to improve diversity (mentoring, pair programming, role models). High school teachers will participate via team-teaching, curriculum development, and professional development (PD) workshops.

This planning grant would enable the PIs to build on their curriculum within the context of the CS10K Project with initial research and development around diversity (in particular, strategies for engaging and retaining Native American students), curriculum (positioning their course offerings in the context of the CS10K effort), and teacher professional development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demand for graduates with computer skills is projected to be one of the fastest growing fields, and many of the related jobs are among the highest paying in the nation. Estimates suggest that the number of computer science (CS) graduates from Montana public colleges and universities meet approximately only 10% of statewide demand. In this STEM+C proposal to broaden participation in CS, collaborators from the three main public flagship institutions in the state of Montana—the University of Montana (UM) in Missoula, Montana State University (MSU) in Bozeman, Montana Tech (MTech) in Butte—and Salish Kootenai Tribal College (SKC) located on the Flathead Indian Reservation in Pablo, Montana, have joined together in a new and unprecedented statewide effort. Our overarching and collective goal is: 1) broaden the CS curriculum available in local public high schools so that more students are exposed to opportunities within CS, and 2) increase the number of qualified computer science high school teachers in the state. The anticipated outcome of our efforts is that more students will engage with various topics and activities within computer science, and subsequently more will ultimately choose it as a career path.

 

To achieve these broad goals, our plan is to: 1) rollout a pair of related courses that cover topical, relevant, and diverse areas of CS to local high schools; 2) offer dual credit and advanced placement (AP) opportunities to students who achieve success in these courses; 3) prepare high-school teachers for fluency in these CS topics by offering hands-on support opportunities for their on-going professional development; 4) engage underrepresented groups, women and Native Americans in particular; and 5) build, assess, and inform our activities using a solid educational research foundation and formative and summative summaries conducted by an external evaluator.

 

The planning grant for which this outcomes report is written has allowed us to further our research and consolidate our plans on a number of critical issues. In particular, we have been able to:

  • More clearly situate our planned high school course offerings within the context of ECS or CS Principles, and clearly define how our courses satisfy the recommended CSP Computational Thinking Practices and Concepts (Big Ideas) framework.
  • Reformulate our professional development plans so that they scale to the entire state and more realistically covers intended content in the time allotted. To address this issue, we now require workshop participants to complete teacher readiness training in the form of an online course in Python programming prior to attending the weeklong summer PD workshops; we will supplement the PD workshops with two weekend-long, face-to-face training sessions throughout the academic year; and we will record all training sessions, archive them to a web repository, and allow participants to review them at any time and from any location.
  • Develop a tighter management plan knit among the various statewide institutions participating in this work. All PIs will attend and co-teach the PD workshops held each summer; additional weekend face-to-face PD meetings were added to our schedule, and our project Web repository will be the result of a united effort, representative of all the PIs, their institutions, and their local schools.
  • Explain more clearly the issues Native American students face, and how we will develop strategies that engage and retain this particular population.
  • Clarify our evaluation plan by further specifying our central question, “Does the three-course CS curriculum broaden participation in CS majors and career pathways?” We also slightly modified our assessment measurements and logic plan.

 

Based on the work achieved in this planning grant, as outlined above, we resubmitted our CS10K proposal and were awarded a 3-year grant which started in September of 2016. That work is currently successfully underway.
